awd_titl_txt: Understanding the Multiscale Mechanics of Nerve Endings to Address Visceral Pain
awd_abstract_narration:
Visceral pain associated with irritable bowel syndrome afflicts 13% of the US population, costing approximately $30 billion annually. Mechanical distension of hollow visceral organs evokes visceral pain. Drugs for visceral pain affect both peripheral and central nervous systems (CNS) due to similar cellular sensory pathways. Patients treated in this way suffer brain and spinal nerve related side effects, and among those, physical dependency and addiction are particularly important. Visceral pain by mechanical distension of organs initiates in the periphery, making it possible that targeting the receptors of biomechanical loading could reduce the brain and spine side effects.  This project aims to understand the biomechanics of visceral nerves as relates to chronic visceral pain. This research will reveal novel therapeutic targets in the nerve ending-tissue complex specific to visceral organs, minimizing CNS side effects and improving health and quality of life for patients suffering chronic visceral pain. This project will engage students from underrepresented groups, particularly women, in middle school, high school and university through integrated outreach.  Research in the PI's and Co-PI's labs will be integrated with outreach and diversity programs at the Danbury Library and UConn to engage students from underrepresented groups, particularly women, in middle school, high school and university.

The overall objective of this project is to understand the multiscale biomechanics of colorectal tissue and the micromechanical environment surrounding sensory nerve endings in both control (healthy) and TNBS-treated (in pain) colorectums. The central hypothesis posits that factors governing visceral mechanosensation and sensitization include: 1) varying mechanical properties across different layers of colorectal tissue (e.g. mucosal, muscular), 2) distinct micromechanics at couplings between nerve endings and their extracellular matrix, and 3) dynamic changes in tissue biomechanics following colorectal tissue damage and nerve ending regeneration (in TNBS-treated colorectum). This work aims to determine: 1) tissue-level biomechanics of mucosal and muscular layers of colorectum from both control (healthy) and TNBS-treated (in pain) mice, 2) micro-mechanical environments of individual colorectal sensory nerve endings from both control and TNBS-treated mice, and 3) the impact of nerve ending stress/strain on functional heterogeneity of visceral neural mechanosensation and sensitization via multiscale modeling and simulation. This project leverages novel approaches, including: a mouse IBS model of pain produced by trinitrobenzene sulfonic acid (TNBS), genetic sensory nerve labeling, optical tissue clearing, and multiscale modeling of mechanosensation together with nonlinear soft tissue biomechanics and imaging of collagen fibers. This research will introduce previously overlooked biomechanics as a critical factor in visceral nociception and pain, establish novel biomechanical tools and expand current knowledge of visceral mechanosensation and pain.

por.por_cntn:
Visceral pain is the cardinal symptom of irritable bowel syndrome (IBS), afflicting 13% of the US population and costing healthcare ~$30bn annually. Unlike other types of pain, visceral pain has a unique biomechanical component: it is mechanical distension/spasm of hollow visceral organs – not heat, cutting or pinching – that reliably evokes pain from these organs. Encoding of mechanical stimuli (i.e. mechanotransduction), relies first on a biomechanical process, namely transmission of bulk mechanical deformation in visceral organs to local stress/strain distribution in microns-thick sensory nerve endings (i.e., afferent endings) in the organ. This then results in generation of action potentials by sensory nerve endings to inform the central nervous system. This NSF-funded research project allows us to conduct focused experimental and computational studies to gain further mechanistic understanding of this biomechanical process that links bulk mechanical stimuli of the colon and rectum (colorectum) to the local mechanical stress and strain around sensory nerve endings. As listed below, we have performed several focal experimental and computational studies on distal colorectum from mice, which is the most widely used species for studying visceral neural encoding and visceral pain.

We developed a biaxial testing setup that allows the quantification of tissue biomechanical properties using small-sized specimen (7x7mm) harvested from mouse colorectum. This allows us for the first time to compare and contrast the mechanical properties of distal colon and rectum, which anatomically are predominantly innervated by the lumbar splanchnic and pelvic nerves, respectively. This approach allows us to demonstrate the different biomechanical tissue properties between the colon and rectum that could underlie the differential neural encoding functions between the splanchnic and pelvic sensory pathways.

In addition, our nonlinear imaging of collagen fibers in the colorectum by second harmonic generation (SHG) reveals a rich and thick network of collagen fibers in the submucosa, indicating that submucosa can be a loading-carrying structure for the colorectum. Previous assumption on the muscular layers as the predominant load-carrying structure of the colorectum is now under challenge by the new data. We further conducted layer-separated biaxial tests on the inner and outer composites of the colorectum, which unequivocally revealed the load-bearing role of the submucosal layer to withstand noxious mechanical distension of the colorectum.

We have also adapted an optical tissue clearing protocol (SeeDB) originally developed for brain tissue to clear mouse colorectum. We implemented the SeeDB protocol on colorectum from transgenic mice in which ~80% extrinsic colorectal afferents were labeled by a yellow fluorescent protein. This novel approach allowed us to systematically quantify the morphology of afferent endings in mouse colorectum. Strikingly, we found that almost all fibers in the submucosa were meandering and curvy, with ~10% showing pronounced curviness, which strongly indicated their specific roles in encoding high-intensity mechanical stimuli that can engage the loose and curvy fibers.

We also used mathematical model to capture the differential mechanical behaviors of sub-layers of the colorectum, which are constitutive models of the colorectal tissue. We then integrated those constitutive models into a finite element model to simulate the biomechanics of distal colorectum. By implementing the finite element model, we established a methodology for precise calculations of the local micromechanical stresses and strains surrounding individual sensory nerve endings embedded in different sublayers of the colorectum. This allows us to develop a multi-scale model that integrates our macro- and microscale mechanical findings to simulate colorectal mechanotransduction.

In summary, our experimental and computational modeling studies have provided compelling evidence to indicate that the submucosal layer is the load-bearing structure of the colorectum, which is also densely innervated by sensory nerve fibers to detect concentrated mechanical stress. Thus, visceral pain evoked by mechanical colorectal distension is likely initiated from sensory nerve endings located in the submucosa of the colorectum. Outcomes of this research have provided a solid foundation for future research that targets those sensory nerve endings in the submucosa for alleviating visceral pain in IBS patients.
